  {"id":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","abstract":"Inspired by the influential “deaths of despair” narrative, which emphasizes the role of worsening economic opportunity in driving the increasing mortality for non-Hispanic Whites in the recent decades, a rising number of studies have provided suggestive evidence that upward mobility levels across counties may partly explain variations in mortality rates. A gap in the literature is the lack of life-course studies examining the relationship between early-life upward mobility and later-life mortality across counties. Another gap is the lack of studies on how the relationship between upward mobility and mortality across counties varies across diverse sociodemographic populations. This study examines differences across race and sex in the relationship between early-life intergenerational upward mobility and early adulthood mortality at the county level. We use administrative data on upward mobility and vital statistics data on mortality across 3030 counties for those born between 1978 and 1983. We control for a variety of county-level socioeconomic variables in a model with fixed effects for state and year. Subgroup analyses by educational attainment and urban status were also performed for each race-sex combination. Results show strong negative relationships between early-life upward mobility and early adulthood mortality across racial-sex combinations, with a particularly greater magnitude for non-Hispanic Black males. In addition, individuals without a college degree and living in urban counties are particularly affected by early life upward mobility. The findings of this study highlight the vulnerability of less-educated, young urban Black males, due to the intersecting effects of the urban context, education, race, and sex.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"}],"citation-key":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","container-title":"Health & Place","DOI":"10.1016/j.healthplace.2021.102628","ISSN":"1353-8292","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",7]]},"language":"english","page":"102628","title":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults: Evidence from county-level analyses","title-short":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults","type":"article-journal","volume":"70"},
  {"id":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","abstract":"Health varies by U.S. region of residence. Despite regional heterogeneity in the outbreak of COVID-19, regional differences in physical distancing behaviors over time are relatively unknown. This study examines regional variation in physical distancing trends during the COVID-19 pandemic and investigates variation by race and socioeconomic status (SES) within regions. Data from the 2015–2019 five-year American Community Survey were matched with anonymized location pings data from over 20 million mobile devices (SafeGraph, Inc.) at the Census block group level. We visually present trends in the stay-at-home proportion by Census region, race, and SES throughout 2020 and conduct regression analyses to examine these patterns. From March to December, the stay-at-home proportion was highest in the Northeast (0.25 in March to 0.35 in December) and lowest in the South (0.24 to 0.30). Across all regions, the stay-at-home proportion was higher in block groups with a higher percentage of Blacks, as Blacks disproportionately live in urban areas where stay-at-home rates were higher (0.009 [CI: 0.008, 0.009]). In the South, West, and Midwest, higher-SES block groups stayed home at the lowest rates pre-pandemic; however, this trend reversed throughout March before converging in the months following. In the Northeast, lower-SES block groups stayed home at comparable rates to higher-SES block groups during the height of the pandemic but diverged in the months following. Differences in physical distancing behaviors exist across U.S. regions, with a pronounced Southern and rural disadvantage. Results can be used to guide reopening and COVID-19 mitigation plans.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"West","given":"Jessica"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"},{"family":"Pao","given":"Christina"}],"citation-key":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","container-title":"PLOS ONE","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0259665","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"11","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",11]]},"language":"english","page":"e0259665","publisher":"Public Library of Science","title":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing: Evaluating racial and socioeconomic divides during the COVID-19 pandemic","title-short":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing","type":"article-journal","volume":"16"}
]

csl.abstract: Health varies by U.S. region of residence. Despite regional heterogeneity in the outbreak of COVID-19, regional differences in physical distancing behaviors over time are relatively unknown. This study examines regional variation in physical distancing trends during the COVID-19 pandemic and investigates variation by race and socioeconomic status (SES) within regions. Data from the 2015–2019 five-year American Community Survey were matched with anonymized location pings data from over 20 million mobile devices (SafeGraph, Inc.) at the Census block group level. We visually present trends in the stay-at-home proportion by Census region, race, and SES throughout 2020 and conduct regression analyses to examine these patterns. From March to December, the stay-at-home proportion was highest in the Northeast (0.25 in March to 0.35 in December) and lowest in the South (0.24 to 0.30). Across all regions, the stay-at-home proportion was higher in block groups with a higher percentage of Blacks, as Blacks disproportionately live in urban areas where stay-at-home rates were higher (0.009 [CI: 0.008, 0.009]). In the South, West, and Midwest, higher-SES block groups stayed home at the lowest rates pre-pandemic; however, this trend reversed throughout March before converging in the months following. In the Northeast, lower-SES block groups stayed home at comparable rates to higher-SES block groups during the height of the pandemic but diverged in the months following. Differences in physical distancing behaviors exist across U.S. regions, with a pronounced Southern and rural disadvantage. Results can be used to guide reopening and COVID-19 mitigation plans.
csl.title: U.S. regional differences in physical distancing: Evaluating racial and socioeconomic divides during the COVID-19 pandemic
csl.title-short: U.S. regional differences in physical distancing

csl.abstract: Inspired by the influential “deaths of despair” narrative, which emphasizes the role of worsening economic opportunity in driving the increasing mortality for non-Hispanic Whites in the recent decades, a rising number of studies have provided suggestive evidence that upward mobility levels across counties may partly explain variations in mortality rates. A gap in the literature is the lack of life-course studies examining the relationship between early-life upward mobility and later-life mortality across counties. Another gap is the lack of studies on how the relationship between upward mobility and mortality across counties varies across diverse sociodemographic populations. This study examines differences across race and sex in the relationship between early-life intergenerational upward mobility and early adulthood mortality at the county level. We use administrative data on upward mobility and vital statistics data on mortality across 3030 counties for those born between 1978 and 1983. We control for a variety of county-level socioeconomic variables in a model with fixed effects for state and year. Subgroup analyses by educational attainment and urban status were also performed for each race-sex combination. Results show strong negative relationships between early-life upward mobility and early adulthood mortality across racial-sex combinations, with a particularly greater magnitude for non-Hispanic Black males. In addition, individuals without a college degree and living in urban counties are particularly affected by early life upward mobility. The findings of this study highlight the vulnerability of less-educated, young urban Black males, due to the intersecting effects of the urban context, education, race, and sex.
csl.title: Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults: Evidence from county-level analyses
csl.title-short: Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults

In the South, West, and Midwest, higher-SES block groups stayed home at the lowest rates pre-pandemic; however, this trend reversed throughout March before converging in the months following. In the Northeast, lower-SES block groups stayed home at comparable rates to higher-SES block groups during the height of the pandemic but diverged in the months following. Differences in physical distancing behaviors exist across U.S. regions, with a pronounced Southern and rural disadvantage. Results can be used to guide reopening and COVID-19 mitigation plans.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"West","given":"Jessica"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"},{"family":"Pao","given":"Christina"}],"citation-key":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","container-title":"PLOS ONE","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0259665","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"11","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",11]]},"language":"english","page":"e0259665","publisher":"Public Library of Science","title":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing: Evaluating racial and socioeconomic divides during the COVID-19 pandemic","title-short":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing","type":"article-journal","volume":"16"}

  {"id":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectPropertyOwnershipConsolidation2023","author":[{"literal":"The Anti-Eviction Mapping Project"}],"citation-key":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectPropertyOwnershipConsolidation2023","issued":{"date-parts":[["2023",9,9]]},"title":"Property Ownership and Consolidation in Concord, 2023","type":"report","URL":"https://antievictionmap.com/blog/2023/9/14/property-ownership-and-consolidation-in-concord-2023"},
  {"id":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectWebinarWorkshopEvictorbook2023","author":[{"literal":"The Anti-Eviction Mapping Project"}],"citation-key":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectWebinarWorkshopEvictorbook2023","issued":{"date-parts":[["2023",7,30]]},"title":"Webinar workshop for Evictorbook: A tool for tenant organizing","type":"speech"},
  {"id":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","abstract":"Inspired by the influential “deaths of despair” narrative, which emphasizes the role of worsening economic opportunity in driving the increasing mortality for non-Hispanic Whites in the recent decades, a rising number of studies have provided suggestive evidence that upward mobility levels across counties may partly explain variations in mortality rates. A gap in the literature is the lack of life-course studies examining the relationship between early-life upward mobility and later-life mortality across counties. Another gap is the lack of studies on how the relationship between upward mobility and mortality across counties varies across diverse sociodemographic populations. This study examines differences across race and sex in the relationship between early-life intergenerational upward mobility and early adulthood mortality at the county level. We use administrative data on upward mobility and vital statistics data on mortality across 3030 counties for those born between 1978 and 1983. We control for a variety of county-level socioeconomic variables in a model with fixed effects for state and year. Subgroup analyses by educational attainment and urban status were also performed for each race-sex combination. Results show strong negative relationships between early-life upward mobility and early adulthood mortality across racial-sex combinations, with a particularly greater magnitude for non-Hispanic Black males. In addition, individuals without a college degree and living in urban counties are particularly affected by early life upward mobility. The findings of this study highlight the vulnerability of less-educated, young urban Black males, due to the intersecting effects of the urban context, education, race, and sex.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"}],"citation-key":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","container-title":"Health & Place","DOI":"10.1016/j.healthplace.2021.102628","ISSN":"1353-8292","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",7]]},"language":"english","page":"102628","title":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults: Evidence from county-level analyses","title-short":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults","type":"article-journal","volume":"70"},
  {"id":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","abstract":"Health varies by U.S. region of residence. Despite regional heterogeneity in the outbreak of COVID-19, regional differences in physical distancing behaviors over time are relatively unknown. This study examines regional variation in physical distancing trends during the COVID-19 pandemic and investigates variation by race and socioeconomic status (SES) within regions. Data from the 2015–2019 five-year American Community Survey were matched with anonymized location pings data from over 20 million mobile devices (SafeGraph, Inc.) at the Census block group level. We visually present trends in the stay-at-home proportion by Census region, race, and SES throughout 2020 and conduct regression analyses to examine these patterns. From March to December, the stay-at-home proportion was highest in the Northeast (0.25 in March to 0.35 in December) and lowest in the South (0.24 to 0.30). Across all regions, the stay-at-home proportion was higher in block groups with a higher percentage of Blacks, as Blacks disproportionately live in urban areas where stay-at-home rates were higher (0.009 [CI: 0.008, 0.009]). In the South, West, and Midwest, higher-SES block groups stayed home at the lowest rates pre-pandemic; however, this trend reversed throughout March before converging in the months following. In the Northeast, lower-SES block groups stayed home at comparable rates to higher-SES block groups during the height of the pandemic but diverged in the months following. Differences in physical distancing behaviors exist across U.S. regions, with a pronounced Southern and rural disadvantage. Results can be used to guide reopening and COVID-19 mitigation plans.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"West","given":"Jessica"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"},{"family":"Pao","given":"Christina"}],"citation-key":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","container-title":"PLOS ONE","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0259665","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"11","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",11]]},"language":"english","page":"e0259665","publisher":"Public Library of Science","title":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing: Evaluating racial and socioeconomic divides during the COVID-19 pandemic","title-short":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing","type":"article-journal","volume":"16"}
]

  {"id":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","abstract":"Inspired by the influential “deaths of despair” narrative, which emphasizes the role of worsening economic opportunity in driving the increasing mortality for non-Hispanic Whites in the recent decades, a rising number of studies have provided suggestive evidence that upward mobility levels across counties may partly explain variations in mortality rates. A gap in the literature is the lack of life-course studies examining the relationship between early-life upward mobility and later-life mortality across counties. Another gap is the lack of studies on how the relationship between upward mobility and mortality across counties varies across diverse sociodemographic populations. This study examines differences across race and sex in the relationship between early-life intergenerational upward mobility and early adulthood mortality at the county level. We use administrative data on upward mobility and vital statistics data on mortality across 3030 counties for those born between 1978 and 1983. We control for a variety of county-level socioeconomic variables in a model with fixed effects for state and year. Subgroup analyses by educational attainment and urban status were also performed for each race-sex combination. Results show strong negative relationships between early-life upward mobility and early adulthood mortality across racial-sex combinations, with a particularly greater magnitude for non-Hispanic Black males. In addition, individuals without a college degree and living in urban counties are particularly affected by early life upward mobility. The findings of this study highlight the vulnerability of less-educated, young urban Black males, due to the intersecting effects of the urban context, education, race, and sex.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"}],"citation-key":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","container-title":"Health & Place","DOI":"10.1016/j.healthplace.2021.102628","ISSN":"1353-8292","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",7]]},"language":"english","page":"102628","title":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults: Evidence from county-level analyses","title-short":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults","type":"article-journal","volume":"70"},
  {"id":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","abstract":"Health varies by U.S. region of residence. Despite regional heterogeneity in the outbreak of COVID-19, regional differences in physical distancing behaviors over time are relatively unknown. This study examines regional variation in physical distancing trends during the COVID-19 pandemic and investigates variation by race and socioeconomic status (SES) within regions. Data from the 2015–2019 five-year American Community Survey were matched with anonymized location pings data from over 20 million mobile devices (SafeGraph, Inc.) at the Census block group level. We visually present trends in the stay-at-home proportion by Census region, race, and SES throughout 2020 and conduct regression analyses to examine these patterns. From March to December, the stay-at-home proportion was highest in the Northeast (0.25 in March to 0.35 in December) and lowest in the South (0.24 to 0.30). Across all regions, the stay-at-home proportion was higher in block groups with a higher percentage of Blacks, as Blacks disproportionately live in urban areas where stay-at-home rates were higher (0.009 [CI: 0.008, 0.009]). In the South, West, and Midwest, higher-SES block groups stayed home at the lowest rates pre-pandemic; however, this trend reversed throughout March before converging in the months following. In the Northeast, lower-SES block groups stayed home at comparable rates to higher-SES block groups during the height of the pandemic but diverged in the months following. Differences in physical distancing behaviors exist across U.S. regions, with a pronounced Southern and rural disadvantage. Results can be used to guide reopening and COVID-19 mitigation plans.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"West","given":"Jessica"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"},{"family":"Pao","given":"Christina"}],"citation-key":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","container-title":"PLOS ONE","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0259665","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"11","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",11]]},"language":"english","page":"e0259665","publisher":"Public Library of Science","title":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing: Evaluating racial and socioeconomic divides during the COVID-19 pandemic","title-short":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing","type":"article-journal","volume":"16"}
]

  {"id":"tahrircoalitionUniversityEndowmentGenocide2024","author":[{"literal":"TAHRIR Coalition"}],"citation-key":"tahrircoalitionUniversityEndowmentGenocide2024","issued":{"date-parts":[["2024",2,15]]},"title":"The University Endowment and the Genocide in Gaza: An Investigation of the University of Michigan Endowment","type":"document","URL":"https://bit.ly/UMEndowmentGuide"},
  {"id":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectEvictorbookToolTenant2022","author":[{"literal":"The Anti-Eviction Mapping Project"}],"citation-key":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectEvictorbookToolTenant2022","issued":{"date-parts":[["2022",5]]},"title":"Evictorbook: A tool for tenant organizing","type":"document","URL":"https://evictorbook.com"},
  {"id":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectPropertyOwnershipConsolidation2023","author":[{"literal":"The Anti-Eviction Mapping Project"}],"citation-key":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectPropertyOwnershipConsolidation2023","issued":{"date-parts":[["2023",9,9]]},"title":"Property Ownership and Consolidation in Concord, 2023","type":"report","URL":"https://antievictionmap.com/blog/2023/9/14/property-ownership-and-consolidation-in-concord-2023"},
  {"id":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectWebinarWorkshopEvictorbook2023","author":[{"literal":"The Anti-Eviction Mapping Project"}],"citation-key":"theanti-evictionmappingprojectWebinarWorkshopEvictorbook2023","issued":{"date-parts":[["2023",7,30]]},"title":"Webinar workshop for Evictorbook: A tool for tenant organizing","type":"speech"},
  {"id":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","abstract":"Inspired by the influential “deaths of despair” narrative, which emphasizes the role of worsening economic opportunity in driving the increasing mortality for non-Hispanic Whites in the recent decades, a rising number of studies have provided suggestive evidence that upward mobility levels across counties may partly explain variations in mortality rates. A gap in the literature is the lack of life-course studies examining the relationship between early-life upward mobility and later-life mortality across counties. Another gap is the lack of studies on how the relationship between upward mobility and mortality across counties varies across diverse sociodemographic populations. This study examines differences across race and sex in the relationship between early-life intergenerational upward mobility and early adulthood mortality at the county level. We use administrative data on upward mobility and vital statistics data on mortality across 3030 counties for those born between 1978 and 1983. We control for a variety of county-level socioeconomic variables in a model with fixed effects for state and year. Subgroup analyses by educational attainment and urban status were also performed for each race-sex combination. Results show strong negative relationships between early-life upward mobility and early adulthood mortality across racial-sex combinations, with a particularly greater magnitude for non-Hispanic Black males. In addition, individuals without a college degree and living in urban counties are particularly affected by early life upward mobility. The findings of this study highlight the vulnerability of less-educated, young urban Black males, due to the intersecting effects of the urban context, education, race, and sex.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"}],"citation-key":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","container-title":"Health & Place","DOI":"10.1016/j.healthplace.2021.102628","ISSN":"1353-8292","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",7]]},"language":"english","page":"102628","title":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults: Evidence from county-level analyses","title-short":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults","type":"article-journal","volume":"70"},
  {"id":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","abstract":"Health varies by U.S. region of residence. Despite regional heterogeneity in the outbreak of COVID-19, regional differences in physical distancing behaviors over time are relatively unknown. This study examines regional variation in physical distancing trends during the COVID-19 pandemic and investigates variation by race and socioeconomic status (SES) within regions. Data from the 2015–2019 five-year American Community Survey were matched with anonymized location pings data from over 20 million mobile devices (SafeGraph, Inc.) at the Census block group level. We visually present trends in the stay-at-home proportion by Census region, race, and SES throughout 2020 and conduct regression analyses to examine these patterns. From March to December, the stay-at-home proportion was highest in the Northeast (0.25 in March to 0.35 in December) and lowest in the South (0.24 to 0.30). Across all regions, the stay-at-home proportion was higher in block groups with a higher percentage of Blacks, as Blacks disproportionately live in urban areas where stay-at-home rates were higher (0.009 [CI: 0.008, 0.009]). In the South, West, and Midwest, higher-SES block groups stayed home at the lowest rates pre-pandemic; however, this trend reversed throughout March before converging in the months following. In the Northeast, lower-SES block groups stayed home at comparable rates to higher-SES block groups during the height of the pandemic but diverged in the months following. Differences in physical distancing behaviors exist across U.S. regions, with a pronounced Southern and rural disadvantage. Results can be used to guide reopening and COVID-19 mitigation plans.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"West","given":"Jessica"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"},{"family":"Pao","given":"Christina"}],"citation-key":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","container-title":"PLOS ONE","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0259665","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"11","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",11]]},"language":"english","page":"e0259665","publisher":"Public Library of Science","title":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing: Evaluating racial and socioeconomic divides during the COVID-19 pandemic","title-short":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing","type":"article-journal","volume":"16"}
]

  {"id":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","abstract":"Inspired by the influential “deaths of despair” narrative, which emphasizes the role of worsening economic opportunity in driving the increasing mortality for non-Hispanic Whites in the recent decades, a rising number of studies have provided suggestive evidence that upward mobility levels across counties may partly explain variations in mortality rates. A gap in the literature is the lack of life-course studies examining the relationship between early-life upward mobility and later-life mortality across counties. Another gap is the lack of studies on how the relationship between upward mobility and mortality across counties varies across diverse sociodemographic populations. This study examines differences across race and sex in the relationship between early-life intergenerational upward mobility and early adulthood mortality at the county level. We use administrative data on upward mobility and vital statistics data on mortality across 3030 counties for those born between 1978 and 1983. We control for a variety of county-level socioeconomic variables in a model with fixed effects for state and year. Subgroup analyses by educational attainment and urban status were also performed for each race-sex combination. Results show strong negative relationships between early-life upward mobility and early adulthood mortality across racial-sex combinations, with a particularly greater magnitude for non-Hispanic Black males. In addition, individuals without a college degree and living in urban counties are particularly affected by early life upward mobility. The findings of this study highlight the vulnerability of less-educated, young urban Black males, due to the intersecting effects of the urban context, education, race, and sex.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"}],"citation-key":"zangIntergenerationalUpwardMobility2021","container-title":"Health & Place","DOI":"10.1016/j.healthplace.2021.102628","ISSN":"1353-8292","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",7]]},"language":"english","page":"102628","title":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults: Evidence from county-level analyses","title-short":"Intergenerational upward mobility and racial differences in mortality among young adults","type":"article-journal","volume":"70"},
  {"id":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","abstract":"Health varies by U.S. region of residence. Despite regional heterogeneity in the outbreak of COVID-19, regional differences in physical distancing behaviors over time are relatively unknown. This study examines regional variation in physical distancing trends during the COVID-19 pandemic and investigates variation by race and socioeconomic status (SES) within regions. Data from the 2015–2019 five-year American Community Survey were matched with anonymized location pings data from over 20 million mobile devices (SafeGraph, Inc.) at the Census block group level. We visually present trends in the stay-at-home proportion by Census region, race, and SES throughout 2020 and conduct regression analyses to examine these patterns. From March to December, the stay-at-home proportion was highest in the Northeast (0.25 in March to 0.35 in December) and lowest in the South (0.24 to 0.30). Across all regions, the stay-at-home proportion was higher in block groups with a higher percentage of Blacks, as Blacks disproportionately live in urban areas where stay-at-home rates were higher (0.009 [CI: 0.008, 0.009]). In the South, West, and Midwest, higher-SES block groups stayed home at the lowest rates pre-pandemic; however, this trend reversed throughout March before converging in the months following. In the Northeast, lower-SES block groups stayed home at comparable rates to higher-SES block groups during the height of the pandemic but diverged in the months following. Differences in physical distancing behaviors exist across U.S. regions, with a pronounced Southern and rural disadvantage. Results can be used to guide reopening and COVID-19 mitigation plans.","author":[{"family":"Zang","given":"Emma"},{"family":"West","given":"Jessica"},{"family":"Kim","given":"Nathan"},{"family":"Pao","given":"Christina"}],"citation-key":"zangRegionalDifferencesPhysical2021","container-title":"PLOS ONE","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0259665","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"11","issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",11]]},"language":"english","page":"e0259665","publisher":"Public Library of Science","title":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing: Evaluating racial and socioeconomic divides during the COVID-19 pandemic","title-short":"U.S. regional differences in physical distancing","type":"article-journal","volume":"16"}
]

entries.name: The Distributed AI Research Institute
entries.description: Creating a data pipeline and conducting time-series analyses for the Student and Campus Protest Events Project.

entries.name: Yale University Department of Statistics & Data Science
entries.description: Guided students through S&DS230: Data Exploration and Analysis during weekly hours. Assisted in creation of midterm and final exams.

entries.name: The Anti-Eviction Mapping Project
entries.description: Active web developer and researcher in the Anti-Eviction Mapping Project, a digital cartography and tenant organizing collective. Began co-coordinating the Evictorbook project for pay in March 2023.

entries.name: DataHaven
entries.description: Wrote reports and performed data analysis for DataHaven, a community action-oriented nonprofit creating reports and data analyses for the Greater New Haven community.

entries.name: Yale Institution for Social and Policy Studies
entries.description: Wrote all data cleaning and modeling code for three papers on social mobility and health with Professor Emma Zang.

entries.name: University of Pennsylvania Population Studies Center
entries.description: Worked with Professor Irma Elo on describing U.S. county-level predictors of mortality. Created a database and Shiny visualization app of demographic county-level indicators.

entries.name: Leadership, Athletics, and Education in Partnership
entries.description: Worked in the Development Office to analyze recent donor data, with the aim of finding relationships between donation time, donation amount, LEAP activities such as segmenting letters, and donor identity.

entries.markup:
• Web development through the Svelte React and Vue frameworks in JavaScript. Familiar with Typescript and the NodeJS and Rust environments for backend server programming.
  • Data visualization through the ggplot2 ecosystem in R as well as the d3.js ecosystem in JavaScript and the plotly library in Python.
  • Expertise in data pipeline creation and data cleaning through the R programming language, especially through the renv and targets frameworks for reproducible development.
  • Web server architecture in the Linux world. Familiar with the Arch, NixOS, Debian, and Gentoo families of Linux distros. Familiar with Docker development and abstractions over these architectures.
